BasicDescription.Title: Performing Bach
BasicDescription.Synopsis: In the second of three programmes exploring favourite Bach works on record, Anthony Burton surveys recordings of the violin concertos.

In the second programme reviewing the history of favourite Bach works on record, Anthony Burton surveys recordings of the ever-popular Violin Concertos by David Oistrakh, Andrew Manze, Gidon Kremer, Yehudi Menuhin, Monica Huggett, Isaac Stern and others.

BasicDescription.Title: BBC Legends
BasicDescription.Synopsis: BBC recordings by the Melos Quartet, including Schubert's Quartet in D, and Beethoven's Quartet in C minor.

BasicDescription.Title: Private Passions
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Michael Berkeley meets Nicholas de Jongh, chief theatre critic of the London Evening Standard, whose choice of music includes Bach, Schubert, Mozart, Richard Strauss and Mahler.

Today Michael Berkeley talks to Nicholas de Jongh, Chief Theatre Critic of The Evening Standard, and author of Politics, Prudery And Perversions, a history of the censorship imposed on the English stage from 1901 until 1968, when a row involving the plays of Edward Bond finally forced the Wilson government to abolish the practice.
Nicholas de Jongh's musical choices include a Bach cello suite, Schubert's Death and the Maiden String Quartet, a Mozart piano concerto, and the closing pages of Strauss' Elektra and Mahler's Ninth Symphony.

BasicDescription.Title: Brian Kay's Light Programme
BasicDescription.Synopsis: This week's selection of music features Eric Coates's Cinderella Phantasy, seasonal pieces from Philip Lane and Kennedy Russell, and Robert Farnon and his orchestra with Vera Lynn.

Eric Coates' Cinderella Phantasy is the main work in today's programme alongside seasonal offerings from Philip Lane and Kennedy Russell, and Robert Farnon and his orchestra team up with Vera Lynn for Once Upon a Winter Time.

BasicDescription.Title: Discovering Music
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Chris de Souza explores the Trittico Botticelliano - Respighi's orchestral evocation of paintings from the Italian Renaissance.

Chris de Souza gets to grips with Ottorino Respighi's vivid depiction of paintings from the Italian Renaissance, the Trittico Botticelliano. Specially-recorded musical illustrations are played by the BBC National Orchestra of Wales conducted by Peter Stark.

BasicDescription.Title: The John Tusa Interview
BasicDescription.Synopsis: John Tusa talks to the distinguished Chinese-American architect I M Pei.

John Tusa continues his series of conversations with some of the world's greatest artistic originators. This week he meets Chinese-American architect, and creator of the Louvre's glass pyramid entrance, I. M. Pei.

BasicDescription.Title: Drama On 3
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Hilary Mantel's dramatisation of her novel The Giant, O'Brien, loosely based on two 18th-century characters, Irishman Charles O'Brien and Scottish scientist John Hunter.

The Giant, O'Brien by Hilary Mantel.
The year is 1781. Our hero is Charles O'Brien, bard and giant.
The Giant, O' Brien is an unforgettable story; lyrical, shocking and spliced by black comedy; Mantel's dialogue is rich and clear and her story, based onfact, is an absorbing portrait of London at the end of the eighteenth century and an acutely observed fable about our fear of the unusual and the foreign. The evidence on which the story is based lies in the Royal College of Surgeons at Lincolns Inn Fields where the bones of the giant, Charles O' Brien can be seen today. His bones measure seven feet ten inches and he was said to have been only twenty-one years old at his death.
